positive.review:
I wonder why this game isn't very popular :\
Do you know what is life? That's literally this game, well, up to finishing school. Your parents have expectations, and you can try to follow them or not, you will grow up anyway.
Peak mini-games, addictive game loop, 2 disappointed parents out of 2.

In the first few playthroughs the grind is mostly just hard, frustrating and repetitive, but you're learning the game anyways and if you stick with it later generations get a lot of bonuses that make it easier to succeed and thereby access all the actual content of the game more easily, like the career paths and the friends stories. My tip is to try to get the hard Requests from your parents as you can get nice bonuses from those if you get lucky and they consent.
好玩的，体内的追求完美的本能被激发让人忍不住想要一代一代玩下去
尼玛，咋学都是大专

wo bu ji dao

xie xie @tonytentacle
yes
meowe

I am Chinese high school students.My real life is very similar to the one in this game.I study,study,study every day,and almost have no time to develop my own personality.I think it will repeat until graduation from university.It is sad,right?I know this game may not good,but it inflects reality well.

I wonder why this game isn't very popular :\
Do you know what is life? That's literally this game, well, up to finishing school. Your parents have expectations, and you can try to follow them or not, you will grow up anyway.
Peak mini-games, addictive game loop, 2 disappointed parents out of 2.

Super fun and TONS of replay value! I love how different parenting styles lead to different kinds of gameplay, and there are sooo many careers to shoot for. Highly recommend if you enjoy Princess Maker, I was a Teenage Exocolonist, or any other raising/life sims. 

My one complaint is some of the minigames (Face battle and student council election) feel slow compared to the rest of the gameplay loop.

Found this a couple years ago from a youtube video, not expecting much. 

This is genuinely one of the few games I play when I get a chance to. It feels like being in a time vacuum. Only downside I've found is the look people give you when you say you're playing a game called "Chinese Parents," despite being very visibly not Chinese.

In the first few playthroughs the grind is mostly just hard, frustrating and repetitive, but you're learning the game anyways and if you stick with it later generations get a lot of bonuses that make it easier to succeed and thereby access all the actual content of the game more easily, like the career paths and the friends stories. My tip is to try to get the hard Requests from your parents as you can get nice bonuses from those if you get lucky and they consent.

This game is Steam’s best Chinese Life Simulator. 

It has so much replayability and it’s not easy to be a completionist.
-	350 Traits / talents
-	150 Professions / jobs
-	9 girls, 9 boys and a bunch of NPCs
-	35 Family heirlooms / buffs
-	5 Gaokao Subjects, including 70 classes
-	21 ways to earn extra money
-	20 essay topics
-	20 decisions
-	48 turns upto 18 yrs old 

The end game is the Gaokao, at the 48th turn, and the game will show your exam results (i.e. how many courses you've learnt), who you got married to, the job position based on your skills, and your first child, which will be your second generation round 2, another 48 turns...and so on.

After 36 hours of playing this game, I got 21/23 achievements unlocked, and haven’t had a run with a Gaokao score > 600/750. So far, I’ve tried 15-ish different career paths, developed different personalities and family traits. 

Here's the 100% achievement guide I made based on my own experience. 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3579764209

There is no inheritance or generational wealth in this game. I guess that will break the economic system. Afterall, the imperial examination system was one of the contributing factor in preventing a persistent hereditary nobility-_-

Neutral+ review. The mini-game portion is certainly addictive and it feels really good clearing a few boards in one day. Every other various event is fun at first but is then the exact same for future cycles. It's really disheartening to dread them more and more each cycle, especially with them being so time-consuming. The game is really charming minus your parents treating you unfairly, especially when you were playing that parent last cycle, but eh, maybe this is true to life.

Surprisingly, this game has A LOT of content. There's surprisingly several pathways you can approach the 'end of your life', and what surprises me even more, the game doesn't end at that, there's more.

I don't think I have much negative things to say, its very straight forward and the tutorials are simple enough to understand and follow. Overall its a nice game to play and get. Also during the sale its not too expensive so like, why not

Ah...the strict Asian household experience... you can ace the exams, focus 100% on studying and you're still not good enough. I enjoyed this game more than I thought I would, it was a fun time killer.
好玩的，体内的追求完美的本能被激发让人忍不住想要一代一代玩下去
I thought this game would be fun, but it's like reliving my childhood trauma...
Bon jeu je recommande mais manque cruellement de main task on commencee a s'ennuyer a partir de 7-8 heure de  jeu
I fear I'm a tiger parent based on how much time I spent on this game. Did not think I would enjoy it as much as I did.

So far I've only played 6 hours... On steam. I tried this originally with the google play app, having completed the free trial, I was left quite sad I would no longer be able to play. I proceeded to get this on both steam and google play. 

If you're feeling sick, fatigued, low energy- I highly reccomend this game. Reminder: 6 hours only on steam... Likely 3 hours on tablet, and will be many more to come!
好玩好玩好玩不解释
尼玛，咋学都是大专

wo bu ji dao

xie xie @tonytentacle

Chinese Parents – “T.b.h... Don't Bother.”

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

I actually really like this game. It’s simple, easy to pick up, and not too hard to manage. Since I last played, the developers have added a pet system, more love interests, and other micro-management features.

That said, it’s very repetitive. After one or two “generations,” you’ve basically seen everything. It feels like a mobile game — same routine, different numbers — with difficulty coming from higher stat requirements rather than new challenges. Your kid gets smarter each generation, but the gameplay loop doesn’t evolve much.

Small gripe: you can’t use spaces or dashes in names, so no authentic options like “Li Wei.”

If I could give a neutral score, I would. But I’ll lean positive — I enjoyed it, even if I wouldn’t recommend it to everyone, especially not at full price.
yu zhong anak pintar matikamatika
china numba 1
yes
meowe

I am Chinese high school students.My real life is very similar to the one in this game.I study,study,study every day,and almost have no time to develop my own personality.I think it will repeat until graduation from university.It is sad,right?I know this game may not good,but it inflects reality well.

I wonder why this game isn't very popular :\
Do you know what is life? That's literally this game, well, up to finishing school. Your parents have expectations, and you can try to follow them or not, you will grow up anyway.
Peak mini-games, addictive game loop, 2 disappointed parents out of 2.

Super fun and TONS of replay value! I love how different parenting styles lead to different kinds of gameplay, and there are sooo many careers to shoot for. Highly recommend if you enjoy Princess Maker, I was a Teenage Exocolonist, or any other raising/life sims. 

My one complaint is some of the minigames (Face battle and student council election) feel slow compared to the rest of the gameplay loop.

Found this a couple years ago from a youtube video, not expecting much. 

This is genuinely one of the few games I play when I get a chance to. It feels like being in a time vacuum. Only downside I've found is the look people give you when you say you're playing a game called "Chinese Parents," despite being very visibly not Chinese.

In the first few playthroughs the grind is mostly just hard, frustrating and repetitive, but you're learning the game anyways and if you stick with it later generations get a lot of bonuses that make it easier to succeed and thereby access all the actual content of the game more easily, like the career paths and the friends stories. My tip is to try to get the hard Requests from your parents as you can get nice bonuses from those if you get lucky and they consent.

This game is Steam’s best Chinese Life Simulator. 

It has so much replayability and it’s not easy to be a completionist.
-	350 Traits / talents
-	150 Professions / jobs
-	9 girls, 9 boys and a bunch of NPCs
-	35 Family heirlooms / buffs
-	5 Gaokao Subjects, including 70 classes
-	21 ways to earn extra money
-	20 essay topics
-	20 decisions
-	48 turns upto 18 yrs old 

The end game is the Gaokao, at the 48th turn, and the game will show your exam results (i.e. how many courses you've learnt), who you got married to, the job position based on your skills, and your first child, which will be your second generation round 2, another 48 turns...and so on.

After 36 hours of playing this game, I got 21/23 achievements unlocked, and haven’t had a run with a Gaokao score > 600/750. So far, I’ve tried 15-ish different career paths, developed different personalities and family traits. 

Here's the 100% achievement guide I made based on my own experience. 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3579764209

There is no inheritance or generational wealth in this game. I guess that will break the economic system. Afterall, the imperial examination system was one of the contributing factor in preventing a persistent hereditary nobility-_-

Neutral+ review. The mini-game portion is certainly addictive and it feels really good clearing a few boards in one day. Every other various event is fun at first but is then the exact same for future cycles. It's really disheartening to dread them more and more each cycle, especially with them being so time-consuming. The game is really charming minus your parents treating you unfairly, especially when you were playing that parent last cycle, but eh, maybe this is true to life.

Surprisingly, this game has A LOT of content. There's surprisingly several pathways you can approach the 'end of your life', and what surprises me even more, the game doesn't end at that, there's more.

I don't think I have much negative things to say, its very straight forward and the tutorials are simple enough to understand and follow. Overall its a nice game to play and get. Also during the sale its not too expensive so like, why not

Ah...the strict Asian household experience... you can ace the exams, focus 100% on studying and you're still not good enough. I enjoyed this game more than I thought I would, it was a fun time killer.
好玩的，体内的追求完美的本能被激发让人忍不住想要一代一代玩下去
I thought this game would be fun, but it's like reliving my childhood trauma...
Bon jeu je recommande mais manque cruellement de main task on commencee a s'ennuyer a partir de 7-8 heure de  jeu
I fear I'm a tiger parent based on how much time I spent on this game. Did not think I would enjoy it as much as I did.

So far I've only played 6 hours... On steam. I tried this originally with the google play app, having completed the free trial, I was left quite sad I would no longer be able to play. I proceeded to get this on both steam and google play. 

If you're feeling sick, fatigued, low energy- I highly reccomend this game. Reminder: 6 hours only on steam... Likely 3 hours on tablet, and will be many more to come!

negative.review:
Nothing is going to stick with me from this game except for the tons of clicks I was able to use while running Bongo Cat in the background. Everything had to be clicked over and over and over to progress to the next screen.

Chinese Parents isn't terrible it's just not good. I would wait until this game is on sale before purchasing.

The visuals range from cute to hideous. I disliked that I couldn't choose a boy or girl. This wouldn't have been such a big deal but I had 3 generations of boys and couldn't unlock girl traits until I started a new legacy. The RNG on the traits is very grindy and I felt like the game was wasting my time.

The music is as repetitive as the game loop. None of the tracks stood out and I never considered, "Wow, I'd love to have the soundtrack to hear this again!"

I felt like an auntie who stands by as their niece or nephew cracks under the immense stress and pressures of childhood while failing to meet the expectations of strict parents. You don't play as the child or the parents, you watch as this family interacts and aside from assigning some classes your role feels pointless.

Other stuff:

The endings don't show the grown child in their chosen profession. That was one of the best things about the Princess Maker series. What am I rewarded with? A static visual novel image of an office, or the street, or whatever.

There are times I wanted to fast forward and that wasn't possible. The competitions are predictable and uninteresting. There are too many mandatory face battles, contests, etc. They'd be more welcome as an optional novelty not a mandatory slog.

The inclusion of a pet somehow lessens the child's stress but added to my own. It's my understanding that the cat was added in an update but why just a gray cat? Why not let me choose from a selection of cats?  Various dog types would be great, even one dog would be fantastic. How about a goldfish?

The inclusion of a pet somehow lessens the child's stress but added to my own. It's my understanding that the cat was added in an update but why just a gray cat? Why not let me choose from a selection of cats?  Various dog types would be great, even one dog would be fantastic. How about a goldfish?

Nothing is going to stick with me from this game except for the tons of clicks I was able to use while running Bongo Cat in the background. Everything had to be clicked over and over and over to progress to the next screen.

Chinese Parents isn't terrible it's just not good. I would wait until this game is on sale before purchasing.

The visuals range from cute to hideous. I disliked that I couldn't choose a boy or girl. This wouldn't have been such a big deal but I had 3 generations of boys and couldn't unlock girl traits until I started a new legacy. The RNG on the traits is very grindy and I felt like the game was wasting my time.

The music is as repetitive as the game loop. None of the tracks stood out and I never considered, "Wow, I'd love to have the soundtrack to hear this again!"

I felt like an auntie who stands by as their niece or nephew cracks under the immense stress and pressures of childhood while failing to meet the expectations of strict parents. You don't play as the child or the parents, you watch as this family interacts and aside from assigning some classes your role feels pointless.

Other stuff:

The endings don't show the grown child in their chosen profession. That was one of the best things about the Princess Maker series. What am I rewarded with? A static visual novel image of an office, or the street, or whatever.

There are times I wanted to fast forward and that wasn't possible. The competitions are predictable and uninteresting. There are too many mandatory face battles, contests, etc. They'd be more welcome as an optional novelty not a mandatory slog.
